coredata.dc:title: Early implementation of the sustainable development goals in construction projects: A Danish case study
coredata.prism:copyright: Â© 2023 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
coredata.dc:creator: Gade, Anne N.
Selman, Aysar D.
coredata.dc:description: The 2030 Agenda is an ambitious step towards sustainable development for the construction industry, which holds great potential for contributing to the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). However, challenges remain regarding the implementation of the goals. This study aims to investigate the level of integration of the SDGs at an early stage of a new school and kindergarten project in Denmark, which seeks to implement 14 of the SDGs and 50 targets actively throughout the project, along with exploring the decision-making process. The case study consists of two parts: interviews with the actors involved in developing the project's vision plan, hereunder prioritising the SDG and targets, followed by an analysis of the building brief, investigating the utilisation of the SDGs and targets. The interview results were designed and analysed through the lens of the values-rules-knowledge model. The results showed that the perceived level of integration of the SDGs differed among the involved actors, and that the targets that were most successfully implemented at this stage were SDGs 4, 9, 12 and 13. The main conclusion were that the SDGs were not a main driver in the decision-making process, due to the lack of measurability and benchmarking in building projects. The results contribute to the current effort toward implementing the SDGs in construction on a project-specific level, and the novelty lies in the analysis of the decision-making process through the values-rules-knowledge-model, the calculation of the SDG implementation percentage, and providing a best-practice example for SDG implementation in a construction project. The authors recommend further research focusing on case studies involving practical examples of SDG implementation in construction projects to support the operationalisation of the SDGs.

Conflicts and barriers in the decision process (values)
The building brief's contributions to the SDGs

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: â³The decision-making perspective, values, rules and knowledge are independent sets of variables and constraints to be considered when selecting an optionâ [27].

row.entry: What was your role in developing the vision plan?
What was your knowledge of the SDGs (how well did you know the SDGs) previous to your involvement in the vision plan development?
What is your overall impression of the SDGs, in the context of construction projects?
Which SDGs are especially important in the project, in your opinion? Why?
Which targets/sub-goals relates to your professional focus?

Do you agree with the (final) choice of targets in the vision plan?
Did you experience conflicts during the prioritisation of the targets in the development of the vision plan?
Are there any targets that should have been included/are missing, in your opinion?
What were the main factors in the choosing of targets for the vision plan?
How does the choice of SDGs and targets correlate/align with your overall strategy for sustainability in the municipality?

How have the SDGs contributed to the project at the current state?
Has the process been different than in previous, similar projects?

How do you see the potential of implementing the SDGs in the specific project?
In your opinion, do the SDGs contribute to a more sustainable project/building?
Do you see any challenges in meeting the SDG targets in the project? If yes, which?
Do you feel that you had the necessary knowledge to prioritize the SDGs in the project at this stage?
Do you have any comments to the process of implementing the SDGs in the development of the vision plan?

How do you ensure that the SDG targets are met throughout the project?
What are the criteria for success?
How do you ensure that the knowledge you gain in the project regarding the SDG implementation is grounded within the organisation, and can strengthen future projects?
Did you experience any limitations regarding the implementation of the SDG during the process of developing the vision plan?
How do you view the SDGs in relation to other concepts for sustainability in the project (e.g., DGNB)?
Do you have any comments to how stakeholders such as politicians, users etc. can contribute to meet the chosen SDG targets?

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: The building brief analysis of the SDG contributions in the KYU case.

row.entry: Targets included in the building brief
Specific SDG contributions of the building brief

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: All residents have equal rights to economic resources, access to basic services and ownership by having shared facilities, including sports and music, located in a public house with a shared kitchen between the daycare centre and the canteen area.

row.entry: 2.1 Provide everyone access to safe and nutritious food

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: A shared production kitchen provides food for school and daycare.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: Promoting mental health and well-being by ensuring good physical activity opportunities: running routes, areas for ball games, skating rinks, peaceful oases, swimming, water activities and clubrooms.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: A public house is established with a sports hall for the children and social cohesion across the district between children, parents, and leisure users.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: Preventing diseases by focusing on indoor climate and health was ensured through DGNB certification criteria for indoor air quality, volatile organic compounds, and the quality of outdoor areas.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: Reducing road traffic accidents by ensuring safe conditions for cyclists and pedestrians, where they have priority over cars.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: Ensure that all people, regardless of functional ability, can move equally and independently in the building, outdoor areas and public space.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: Level-free building design that ensures equal access and use of the building and outdoor areas.

row.entry: 3.9 Illness and death, pollution, and chemicals

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: Reducing the number of deaths and illnesses from hazardous chemicals and air, water and soil pollution and contamination. Focus on indoor climate and health is obtained through DGNB certification criteria:
â¢Establishing an efficient mechanical ventilation system.
â¢Registration of indoor climate data and room control regarding heating valves, solar shading devices, daylight, artificial lighting, and window handles, all connected to one control system.

â¢Eliminating environmental risks related to construction products, ensuring that building materials are not harmful to the environment and do not risk affecting soil, air, groundwater and surface water, flora, fauna and human health, the built-in materials must be mapped and documented following the DGNB manual.

â¢A large-scale pollution study has been conducted on the Stigsborg area, showing the site is highly contaminated. A clear strategy for managing pollution is defined for the site. Due to the particular soil contamination conditions, the entire water supply system pipes will be carried out in a special tightness class.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: The KYU building established by Aalborg Municipality provides free education to all children.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: The project provides high-quality education for children to prepare them for primary education. The KYU building includes a school with around 1000 pupils, with school leisure facilities and a new daycare centre with a nursery for 60 children and a kindergarten for 100 children.

row.entry: 4.4 Young people and adults with relevant skills

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: The KYU building should provide facilities where children and young people can develop and form a meaningful life.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: The building should facilitate that the children can sense, experience, wonder, explore, experiment and learn through nature's resources and opportunities.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: Outdoor unheated learning environments will be designed e.g., crafts, woodwork or other teaching based on recycled materials from the construction site.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: The project seeks to create diverse learning environments that support small and large learning communities and relationships across generations, gender, age, skills, subjects, teaching and leisure. Many of the building's learning environments will be available to the district's residents outside the institutions' opening hours, ensuring that all people, regardless of functional ability, can move equally and independently in the public space.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: Sustainability elements must be visible and available for learning about sustainability and SDGs throughout the construction process and the completed project.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: Ensuring that the vision of a sustainable building is disseminated and adopted by the daily users.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: Necessary building facilities and functions are conceived as learning environments that can be brought into play in education.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: Designing rooms so knowledge of the current indoor climate is available in an easy-to-understand way.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: Visualising a circular economy, where recycled materials such as reused bricks can be seen, thus helping to create a sustainability narrative.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: Building materials, furniture solutions and SMART solutions where building data can be available for education.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: The building is intended to contribute to sustainable behaviour, e.g., waste management, recycling, energy reduction, and improving indoor climate and water consumption.

row.entry: 4.a Build and upgrade safe, inclusive and effective educational institutes

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: The project is designed to create diverse, differentiated, and varied learning environments indoors and outdoors. The school, kindergarten, and nursery, associated with school leisure facilities, are built and upgraded as an integrated project to promote a safe education, considering child welfare, disability, and gender to create a safe, non-violent, inclusive, and effective learning environment for everyone.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: The school creates effective learning environments, as it must be SMART City learning lab and local town hall in leisure with inclusive activity opportunities.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: The project seeks to create learning environments that provide equal opportunities for all genders.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: The supply of fresh, naturally cooled tap water will be accessible to all users in the building.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: Due to the special soil contamination conditions, the local water supplier will carry out their entire supply system with water pipes in a special tightness class. The water pipe system should be performed in the same tightness class as additional security for clean drinking water.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: Increasing recycling by leading the stormwater to the fjord. Rainwater is collected and used for playing, learning and kitchen gardens.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: Using renewable energy via fjord cooling of the commercial areas and electricity supply via solar cells.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: Creating a concept to reduce energy consumption on construction sites.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: Photovoltaic systems that can produce 10% of the building's total annual electricity consumption

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: The heat supply system will be based on a special low-temperature district heating.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: Fjord cooling of commercial areas and electricity supply via solar cells.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: Establishing a district cooling station near the building will benefit the development of the entire area.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: Implement a circular economy to support a circular region using reused bricks from local markets collected from old demolished Danish buildings.

row.entry: 8.3 Use a policy that creates jobs and lets businesses grow

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: Creating facilities for start-up professions, such as a temporary container village and placing redundant premises in new construction available at affordable rent.

row.entry: 8.4 Use resources efficiently in consumption and production (Sustainable consumption pattern)

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: Reducing resources by establishing sharing, exchanging and recycling facilities for the district, such as part of a parking house and in the form of decentralised sharing and exchange stations in the individual buildings, is inspired by the sharing economy mindset.

row.entry: 8.6 Help more young people into work, education, and training. Youth employment

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: Educating and training children and young, providing workshops for handcrafts to lead them towards higher education and help them in future jobs.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: The Danish authorities' requirements for the working environment must be met regarding building design and layout.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: Ensuring safety when cleaning, mechanical maintenance or repair work may involve physical injury, e.g., providing safety switches in front of all installations.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: Promoting inclusive, sustainable development and innovative solutions, e.g., having a unified SMART parking solution for the district and dual use between residential and commercial areas. Also, parking houses are prepared for electric cars and car-sharing.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: Incorporation of a circular economy, the highest priority is long service life.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: Focus on a sustainable construction site with minimised fossil waste sorting and recycling.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: Circular playgrounds and furniture and recycling some materials from the construction site.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: Flexible design: Design for Disassembly by collecting rainwater for play, learning and utility gardens.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: The Stigsborg area must be a leading example of social, environmental, and economic sustainability and Smart City using technologies and data to create more sustainable development, innovative solutions and citizenship.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: SMART technologies incorporated: Ventilation system, indoor climate detection, energy consumption, self-generating components, and other SMART technologies.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: The area is equipped with municipal cables with the latest digital infrastructure. Establishing empty pipes inroads for flexible digital infrastructure replacement.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: Ensure that all people, regardless of functional ability, can move equally in the building, outdoor areas and public space.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: A level-free design ensures equal access and use of the building and outdoor areas.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: The youth building must act as a dynamo for expanding the neighbourhood â a townhouse that can be used by all children and young people, staff, local community association and cultural life.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: Providing traffic solutions, including a bridge, roads, streets, walking and cycling links. It supports access and traffic flow,

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: Ensuring that people with functional ability can move safely and independently in the building, outdoor areas and public space.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: Making urban areas sustainable by developing the city structure, including a new bridge, roads, streets, walking and cycling links. The youth building will act as a townhouse for the growing community, shaping the district.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: Green building practices are integrated into urban development to enhance environmental sustainability and resilience. The building location is in the node for the district's upcoming paths, on the edge of a nearby park and in the first parquet to the fjord, with direct access to the area's unique qualities.

row.entry: 11.6 Mitigating environmental impact, improving air quality, and reducing- waste

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: Improving air quality by adopting cleaner energy sources.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: Promoting public transportation through good service with public transport and providing space for bike parking.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: Using waste management practices.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: Creating green spaces will contribute to maintaining biodiversity and providing ecosystem services.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: The area's unique location next to the park and fjord with great values must be experienced and used actively by children and staff in the youth building. It creates a basis for working with sustainability and understanding the interaction between man, society, and nature. The area, fjord and sustainability are meaningful objects for pedagogical work in daycare, school, and leisure activities.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: Create a building that is genuinely sustainable throughout its life cycle. Sustainability must be considered holistically to embrace more than resources, material selection and execution methods. Outdoor unheated learning environments create a sustainable construction site through circular economy strategies, e.g., waste sorting, recycling, reused materials and fossil-minimised construction sites.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: Also, Life Cycle Assessment (LCA) and Life Cost Calculations (LCC) are used.
â¢Establishing utility gardens and an outdoor kitchen to process and prepare food from the fjord, gardens, and nature can help support learning under the theme âFrom farm and fjord to table.'

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: Reducing necessary noise measures from external noise, such as traffic noise. Windows, doors, facades, glass partitions, roofs, and the like must be designed to comply with all applicable sound requirements.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: The highest priority is long service life, maintenance, recycling, refurbishment, and material recycling.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: Reducing waste as efficiently as possible by using recycled materials in buildings and playgrounds.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: Sort waste and resources correctly so that the highest possible waste hierarchy level can be achieved to increase reuse and recycling.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: Reduce the amount of waste produced by proper storage of building materials, a planned supply of building materials in quantities, use knowledge of return orders to build markets or material suppliers and benefit from partnerships with traders dealing in used building materials, collecting rainwater used for play, learning and utility gardens.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: Create a sustainable construction site with minimised fossil and energy consumption.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: In cooperation with seven countries, Circular purchasing practices can use this large shopping muscle to promote the circular economy.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: Facilitating digital data collection on energy consumption and indoor climate. Establishing fill detectors on waste containers.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: Working with the local diversion of rainwater on terrain via green rainwater solutions. Water must be included as a recreational element in urban spaces and promote learning by clarifying water circuits and ensuring that rainwater solutions do not cause leaching of soil contamination.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: Create a building that does not exploit the planet's resources and does not contribute to inappropriate climate change or degraded biodiversity.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: A terrain model has been developed for the construction field and the surrounding areas. The areas are desired to be raised as part of the climate protection and are covered with filler soils of varying thickness.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: Motivate children, young people, and adults to take care of the planet more appropriately by staying in a building that inspires climate-conscious care and management in indoor and outdoor physical environments and pedagogical learning environments.

row.entry:
14.1 Pollution of the sea from land
14.2 Protection of marine
14.5 Protection of coastal and marine areas

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: Dealing with the pollution from the Kemira ground by soil filling and coastal advance.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: Ensuring future bathing water quality in the fjord.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: Ensure that the building materials are not harmful to the environment and do not risk negatively affecting soil, air, surface water, flora, fauna, and human health. The embedded materials must be mapped and documented by the DGNB requirements.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: Contaminated rainwater, e.g., from areas of car traffic, must be cleaned in visible green rainwater solutions, while clean rainwater, e.g., from roof water, can be diverted directly to the fjord without purification.

row.entry: 14.7 Increase the economic benefits of sustainable use of marine resources

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: With the location, the building will be a landmark with a maritime identity, marking itself on Aalborg's side of the fjord. Providing recreational access to the water and chances for water activities.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: The park promenade is built as a car-free zone with programs related to school, residential and leisure, such as a schoolyard, sports activities, play, and cafÃ© life. The youth building contributes to and ensures ecosystems' diversity and high biofactor. Actions that encourage and support existing species are necessary and are used as a learning resource.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: Contribute to strengthening Aalborg city biodiversity on a local and municipal scale, creating space for new urban life in a modern nature park. By incorporating raw materials from Aalborg's underground as a growth layer for different habitats in the park, the ambition is to achieve a unique botanical collection and a park with good biodiversity.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: A minimum of 90% of all wood material used in the building and the construction process is documented using Forest Stewardship Council (FSC) and Program for the Endorsement of Forest Certification (PEFC) certified and recycled wood, accordingly, promoting sustainable forests.

row.entry:
15.4 Protection of biodiversity
15.5 Protection of animal species

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: The park will create space for new urban life in a modern nature park with a variated biodiversity. It is of great importance that the surrounding nature - flora and fauna, is preserved and improved.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: Optimised construction process and arrangement of the construction site.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: Establishing a common meeting place to include information about the stage of the construction and the project's visions regarding the building and its surroundings.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: School classes in the city, residents and other stakeholders can get information about the construction.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: The KYU project is part of an EU-funded research and development project S2C âScandinavian Sustainable Circular Construction.â The KYU project is also a partner in the Circular Public Procurement, between 10 partners from 6 countries in the Baltic Sea region and a partner from the Netherlands. The aim is to build more sustainable and energy-efficient public buildings.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: The vision process consisted of workshops, meetings, and days of inspiration, where teachers, educators, students, parents, politicians, consultants, companies, and stakeholders participated.

list-item.label: â¢
list-item.para: Establishing a partnership with Aalborg Municipality to create better conditions for developing health, sports, and communities in the new city district.

head.ce:title: Early implementation of the sustainable development goals in construction projects: A Danish case study

sa:affiliation.sa:organization: Department of Architectural Technology and Construction Management

ce:affiliation.ce:source-text: Department of Architectural Technology and Construction Management, University College of Northern Denmark, Sofiendalsvej 60, 9200, Aalborg, Denmark

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The 2030 Agenda is an ambitious step towards sustainable development for the construction industry, which holds great potential for contributing to the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). However, challenges remain regarding the implementation of the goals. This study aims to investigate the level of integration of the SDGs at an early stage of a new school and kindergarten project in Denmark, which seeks to implement 14 of the SDGs and 50 targets actively throughout the project, along with exploring the decision-making process. The case study consists of two parts: interviews with the actors involved in developing the project's vision plan, hereunder prioritising the SDG and targets, followed by an analysis of the building brief, investigating the utilisation of the SDGs and targets. The interview results were designed and analysed through the lens of the values-rules-knowledge model. The results showed that the perceived level of integration of the SDGs differed among the involved actors, and that the targets that were most successfully implemented at this stage were SDGs 4, 9, 12 and 13. The main conclusion were that the SDGs were not a main driver in the decision-making process, due to the lack of measurability and benchmarking in building projects. The results contribute to the current effort toward implementing the SDGs in construction on a project-specific level, and the novelty lies in the analysis of the decision-making process through the values-rules-knowledge-model, the calculation of the SDG implementation percentage, and providing a best-practice example for SDG implementation in a construction project. The authors recommend further research focusing on case studies involving practical examples of SDG implementation in construction projects to support the operationalisation of the SDGs.

ce:data-availability.ce:para: Data will be made available on request.

ce:section.ce:para: The 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development was agreed upon in 2015 by the 193 member states of the Unites Nations (UN) and marks a global milestone in the field of sustainability and sustainable development [1]. The Agenda includes 17 goals for sustainable development (SDGs), supported by 169 targets and 231 global indicators, divided equally between environmental, social and economic sustainability dimensions (United Nations, 2015). The SDGs are concise and easy to communicate, providing a global and stable definition of sustainable development, which can be valuable for establishing a common ground for sustainable development within the construction industry [2]. The SDGs incorporate all dimensions of sustainable development in a balanced and interlinked manner, offering a better understanding of the relationship between social, economic, and environmental dimensions of sustainability [3]. With the construction industry being responsible for around 40% of energy use and one-third of greenhouse gas emissions worldwide, the environmental aspects are urgent. However, a holistic perspective is necessary to ensure healthy, high-quality buildings without compromising the environmental and economic aspects. The 2030 Agenda offers a holistic framework on an overall level. However, the SDGs and targets must be translated to local and project-specific levels to become operational [1,4,5]. In Denmark, an action plan towards 2030 was presented by the Danish government in 2017 [6], and local SDG indicators have been developed to adapt the SDGs to a Danish context and establish a national baseline for the implementation of the SDGs [7]. To ensure successful adaption and implementation of the SDGs in construction projects, all involved actors in the value chain hold a responsibility for implementing the goals and pushing the sustainability agenda towards 2030. However, the professional building owners are responsible for setting ambitious goals for sustainability at the project's start and including specific requirements in the tender documents.

A previous study among Danish building owners has shown that the main barriers to implementing the SDGs in construction, both strategically and on a project level, are lack of knowledge, limited time and resources, and lack of tools and methods supporting the process [8]. One way to support professional building owners and advisors in implementing the SDGs in construction projects is to provide practical knowledge, including examples and case studies representing best practices. Therefore, case studies providing insights into the decision-making process related to the implementation of the SDGs, along with specific goals and examples of SDG contribution can be valuable to researchers and practitioners within the filed. The objective of this study is to investigate the operationalisation of the SDGs and targets in the early stage of a new building project in Denmark through a case study: a new school and a daycare centre for kids aged 0â15 years. Actors involved in the development of a vision plan for the project were interviewed to interrogate the decision process related to the prioritisation and implementation of SDGs and targets. Subsequently, based on the vision plan, the building brief was analysed to investigate the level of implementation of SDGs and targets and how these were operationalised into specific functionalities and requirements for the new building. The results provide valuable insights into the practical application of the SDGs in a construction project and can benefit both practitioners within the building industry and researchers in the field of sustainable building design. Furthermore, it contributes to the current effort towards implementing the SDGs in construction on a project-specific level, contributing to achieving the 2030 Agenda.

The article is structured as follows. First, the background for the study is presented in the introduction section, including a literature review to provide a state-of-the-art overview of the SDGs in the built environment. Furthermore, an introduction to the case project is provided, along with a presentation of the values-rules-knowledge (VRK) model, which is utilised as an analytical framework for investigating the decision process of SDG implementation in the vision plan. Then, the methods are presented, hereunder the research question and the methods for interviews and analysis of the building brief. The results section is divided into two parts: the results of the interviews and the results of the building brief analysis. The findings are then discussed, and the conclusions are summed up.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Literature review â SDGs in construction
ce:section.ce:para: In recent years, sustainable building design has gained increasing attention in the academic literature. However, the literature investigating how the construction industry can contribute to achieving the 2030 Agenda is still limited. Goubran and Cucuzzella [2] presented a state-of-the-art review of how the SDGs have been utilised in sustainable building design and proposed two analytical mapping tools for tracking SDG integration in building projects. A research agenda for addressing the SDGs in construction was presented by Thuesen and Opoku [9], highlighting four research areas: 1) an understanding of the relationship between the goals, 2) developing measures for evaluating progress, 3) addressing the target with specific projects and 4) facilitating of knowledge transfer. Opoku [3] investigated the role of the built environment in achieving the SDGs, highlighting that the built environment, in particular, can contribute to society's socioeconomic development and well-being. Also, Goubran [10] identified SDG targets that depend directly or indirectly on construction activities, concluding that 17% of the SDG targets are directly dependent on the construction industry's activities, and 27% are indirectly dependent.

Various frameworks to support the process of achieving the SDGs have been developed, e.g. the SDG Compass [11], providing a guide for business action on the SDGs, SDG Capture [12], which is a dialogue tool for spotting possibilities for innovation and sustainability, the SDG impact assessment tool (Chalmers University of Technology and University of Gotheborg, 2020), which is an online tool for assessing how an activity, organisation or innovation affects the SDGs, and, lastly, the SDG impact tool [13], which supports the user in evaluating business and society impacts related to the SDGs. Furthermore, Grainger-Brown et al. [14] have reviewed existing tools and frameworks for strategic implementation of the SDGs in organisations. The existing tools and frameworks are mainly conceptual and not adapted to the construction industry and building projects' specific needs [2,4]. While the 2030 Agenda and the SDGs provide a global framework for sustainable development, assessment frameworks for sustainable construction already exist and have been adapted to local contexts. These sustainability assessment frameworks can potentially support the operationalisation of the SDGs in construction. The links between several of the existing assessment frameworks and the SDGs have been explored in the literature. Alawneh et al. [15] investigated the link between several LEED criteria and the SDG, along with the broader contribution of six rating systems (LEED, BREEAM, CASBEE, Green Star, Green Mark and GBI) to the SDGs [16]. Miyazaki et al. [17] have looked at the link between CASBEE and the SDGs, and the Danish Green Building Council(2018) have mapped how the DGNB-DK criteria contribute to the SDGs and documented SDG contributions can carry extra credits in the latest DGNB-DK assessment manual.

Several case studies that focus explicitly on implementing SDG in construction have been presented in the academic literature. Allen et al. [18] adopted an integrated assessment approach to support the prioritisation of SDG targets through a case study for 22 countries in the Arab region, assessing and prioritising SDG targets based on their âlevel of urgencyâ, âsystematic impactâ and âpolicy gapâ. Goubran and Cucuzzella [2] investigated the implementation of the SDGs in an energy-positive building in Quebec by testing two proposed analytical mapping tools. The mapping tools were used during the integrated design process to track the integration of SDGs in the building project and to analyse the building design approaches and visions about the topics of the goals. Palliyaguru et al. [19] argue that there is a clear and critical need to empower rural communities in Sri Lanka to achieve the SDGs. They present the need for an integrated framework for sustainable building design and construction in the rural context, specifically focusing on the Ampara region of Sri Lanka, to address prevailing physical, social, and cultural issues. Manjia et al. [20] proposed a methodology for implementing sustainable construction indicators for social infrastructure. They identified objectives related to sustainable construction, applied to the case of a construction project in Cameroon. In addition to these studies, global cases of SDG implementation can be found in the two books âAn Architecture Guide to the UN 17 Sustainable Development Goalsâ volumes 1 and 2 [21,22]. Only one of the cases found in the literature investigated how the SDGs were implemented in a building project, along with the related building design approaches and level of implementation. This gap in the literature calls for research to provide cases of SDG implementation in construction projects to support professional building owners, advisors and researchers with knowledge of how the built environment can contribute to achieving the relevant SDGs and targets.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Case presentation: A new building for kids and youth in the Northern part of Denmark
ce:section.ce:para: The case investigated is a new building in the northern part of Denmark, which will include a new school and a daycare centre for kids aged 0â15 years (the building is called the Kids and Youth Universe, hereafter referred to as the KYU building). Furthermore, the building will house leisure and sports activities for kids and youth. The building owner is the municipality of Aalborg, Denmark, and the new building is part of a large development project for a whole new area of the city of Aalborg. Therefore, the project has gained significant political focus and interest, and so has the focus on adopting sustainable solutions for the project, both regarding the physical building and the pedagogical visions for the building. This article focuses on the programming phase, where an initial vision plan was made as a foundation for the building brief. The new building will aim towards a DGNB gold certification, along with achieving the specific sustainability goals of the vision plan and the building brief. The case has been selected for investigation because of the explicit focus on implementing SDGs and sustainable solutions.

A vision plan was developed for the KYU building, describing the initial ideas and needs of the building owner organisation, including both the visions for the physical building, along with a pedagogical vision. The vision plan took its point of departure in the overall vision for the area and served as a foundation for the building brief. Physical and pedagogical visions were described as interlinked and intended to support each other, also from a sustainability perspective. The vision plan was developed by actors from different departments of the municipality, to ensure anchoring broadly in the organisation, along with external advisors counting both architects and engineers, and end-users. Apart from providing a foundation for the building brief, the vision plan also served to document the visions and ideas to a broader public audience.

Research has shown that the SDGs were not adapted to fit the construction industry context. One of the main characteristics of the construction industry is uncertainty, risk, and many changes [25,26]. In order to adapt the SDG to a construction industry context, the decisions that the practitioners need to make are subject to the industry's dynamic nature. For a better understanding of how decisions play into SDG's and the industry's context, we have applied Gorddard et al. [27] âs decision-making perspective called Values-Rule-Knowledge (VRK). The decision-making model, Fig. 1 , is a framework for analysing and diagnosing the institutional, value-based, and informal factors that constrain or enable decisions [27].

The VRK model has been applied as an analytical framework and procedure to help identify and interrogate the context of decisions and behaviours. The model provides a structured approach to investigate and understand the complex interaction between the system of values, rules and knowledge that enable and constrain the decision context. Specifically, VRK has been used to frame the empirical inquiry and for analysing the interactions between the individual perspectives. The approach is elaborated in the methods section. The dimensions of the VRK model are shown in Table 1 and have been used as a foundation for designing the interview guide, presented in the methods section.

This section presents the overall research methodology. Then, the methods for conducting the interviews are presented, including the theoretical framework applied for analysing the interviews, followed by the method for analysing the building brief. A pragmatic philosophical perspective was adopted in the study.

By conducting a single-case study method with multiple units of analysis [29], this study aims to investigate the implementation of the SDGs in the programming phase of a new building for kids and youth in Denmark, answering the following research question: Which role did the SDGs and targets play in the development of the vision plan for the project, and how are the SDG targets utilised in the building brief? The research process is shown in Fig. 2 and comprised three main activities: 1) A desktop review of the relevant documentation from the building owner, including the vision plan for the whole area and the building itself, emphasising the sustainability goals. Also, the researchers took part in initial building meetings. 2) Qualitative interviews were held with the actors involved in the development of the vision plan to investigate the SDG implementation and prioritisation process, and 3) analysis of the building brief for the new building, investigating the utilisation of the SDGs and targets at this stage.

The first part of the research question is approached through qualitative, semi-structured interviews with the actors involved in developing the vision plan. Following Kvale's [30] process for planning and conducting semi-structured interviews, an interview guide was designed as the first part of the process. The interview questions were structured and designed using the VRK framework [27] to ensure that the relevant dimensions of the decision context were included following the process of [28].
The interview questions are shown in Table 2 , including the predominant aspects in relation to the VRK model (values, rules and knowledge).

The group developing the vision plan involved actors from different departments of the municipality, both the internal technical building advisors and urban developers, economists, representatives from the school and daycare departments, along with user representatives from both school, daycare, and local politicians. After initial conversations with the project managers from the different departments within the municipality, the researchers carefully selected seven actors who had been most involved in the process and, therefore, could provide the most detailed insights into the process. The roles of the interviewees were: an internal construction advisor, the manager of the internal construction department, a development consultant in the educational department of the municipality, the local town counsellor of education, the director of education for the municipality, the vice school manager, the administrator of the overall development of the area. Due to COVID-19 restrictions, all interviews were conducted online using MS Teams during the spring of 2020. Subsequently, the interviews were transcribed and condensed following the process of Kvale [30] and analysed using an abductive approach. The results of the interviews were categorised according to the relevant VRK dimensions.

The second part of the research question was approached by analysing the building brief. The analysis was conducted to identify which SDGs and targets the building brief implicitly contributed to, along with the implementation level of each SDG in the KYU building. First, the requirements described in the building brief contributing to the SDGs and their targets were identified. Then, to evaluate the level of implementation of the SDGs, the Implementation Percentage of the targets (IP) was calculated by defining the total number of targets used for each SDG in the building brief in relation to the total number of SDG targets defined by the EU, accordingly, evaluating the SDGs implementation impact. The calculation process was developed by the authors and is elaborated in the results section.

First, the results of the interviews with the actors involved in creating the vision plan are presented, followed by the results of the building brief analysis, investigating the utilisation and potential contributions to the SDGs within the project at this stage.

In this section, the interview results are presented and structured according to the VRK analysis results. Overall, the interviews revealed that in practice, the SDG framework was perceived as abstract and challenging to adapt on a project-specific level.

Overall, the interviewees had some general knowledge regarding the SDGs prior to their participation in the development of the vision plan. Most interviewees knew the SDG headlines but not the targets and indicators. The SDGs were seen as the overall framework for the project in terms of sustainable development and had a high political focus. However, the SDGs were perceived as abstract and not specific enough to be operational in a construction context. Furthermore, it was expressed that the targets were not directly applicable in a Danish context, as most indicators would automatically be met by the project being following Danish laws and the Danish building regulation. One interviewee expressed that: "Because we already had the DGNB framework, the SDGs did not result in a more sustainable building. But if we did not already have DGNB, the SDGs would definitely contribute to a more sustainable approach in the project."

The SDGs did, therefore, not raise the bar significantly regarding the sustainable initiatives made in the project. However, the SDGs did provide an accessible, and easy to understand, framework for discussing the overall prioritizations in the project and ensured a holistic approach to the sustainability discussion, both from a pedagogical and a technical perspective. In that way, the SDGs provided a common language for discussions regarding the sustainability aspects on a national and global level, which made it easier to collaborate across the different administrations within the municipality during the process of developing the vision plan. Furthermore, it was expressed that the SDGs were also a valuable tool as a foundation for the dialogue with occupants and other stakeholders.

The SDGs were perceived as a broad framework that could fit many aspects of the project, but as no documentation is formally required it was âeasyâ to say that the goals would be met, in opposition to the DGNB certification where documentation is required. The interviewees expressed that it was challenging to make the SDG operational â measurability and benchmarking are needed. Specific tools for measuring and benchmarking are called for in a Danish context by the involved actors, especially regarding the construction site and waste management. It was underpinned that the 2030 Agenda is not an operational tool, and therefore it could not be used as such in the process of developing the vision plan. In this project, the SDGs contributed to support the overall principles of sustainability, and it contributed positively to the political agenda, as the vision plan was a political document forming the base for the building brief.

It is a goal that the project will aim to be DGNB gold certified. The interviewees expressed that DGNB-DK framework provided a measurable framework for setting sustainability goals in the project, however primarily from the technical perspective and not explicitly the pedagogical perspective. The SDG framework supported the prioritisation of DGNB criteria, and the SDGs prioritised for the whole area provided an initial frame for this prioritisation. From previous experience, the municipality as building owner prioritised to have a high level of involvement in the DGNB certification process, and thereby in prioritising the criteria, and not leave this responsibility to the contractor. In that way, the municipality would have a more hands-on role in the process of prioritising criteria, and not only the final assessment result. Additionally, the importance of mapping the DGNB criteria to the SDGs were highlighted as a foundation for the process.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Conflicts and barriers in the decision process (values)
ce:section.ce:para: The interviewees were asked to elaborate on the process of prioritising the SDGs. The project group went through the list of SDGs and checked off which they already could automatically meet through the project (e.g., quality education). Also, they went through the DGNB criteria to see which criteria were linked to contribute to specific targets, based on a publication on the links between DGNB-DK and the SDGs by GBC-DK [24]. As a comment to this process, one interviewee expressed that some of the SDGs the project seeks to contribute to were a bit âfar-fetchedâ. The priorities of the SDGs were different from the different administrations within the municipality. E.g., the school administration primarily prioritised the goals related to SDG 4 (quality education), and the building administration prioritised the goals directly related to the building throughout the building's life cycle. However, there were no markable conflicts between the prioritisations, and they easily came to an agreement, it was expressed. Naturally, the different administrations brought different perspectives into the discussion, and that contributed to mutual inspiration. The biggest challenge was to convince the decision makers at the political level that the project would not be too expensive due to the focus on sustainability. It was a goal for the municipality that the sustainability goals should be an integrated part of the project and not make the project more expensive. In the perspective of the building administration, the sustainability aspects were common sense, but the politicians needed to be convinced. Apart from the economical barrier, it was also perceived as a barrier that the SDG headlines were very broad and not specific enough, even on an indicator level.

The KYU project is expected to contribute to 14 of the 17 SDGs, directly and indirectly. It is up to the main contractor how these specifically will be achieved, and the level of achievement will be a competition parameter in the tendering process. The interviewees expressed that it is important to view the SDGs as a whole, as they are interconnected and interdependent. Based on the overall vision for the area, three main themes were in focus from an environmental perspective: climate, resources, and biodiversity. It was also perceived as important that the some of the sustainability aspects will be physically visual in the final building, and will be integrated as a part of the pedagogical practice of the school, such as including energy and indoor environmental data in the teaching, have visible reused materials, etc. The KYU building itself should foster sustainability awareness for the users of the building and invite and inspire to a more sustainable behaviour among both pupils and teachers.

ce:section.ce:section-title: The building brief's contributions to the SDGs
ce:section.ce:para: This section presents the results of the analysis of the building brief's specific contributions to the SDGs and targets. The analysis was done by reading through the requirements described in the building brief, and identifying which SDGs and targets they contribute to â if applicable. The requirements and the related SDGs and targets are shown in Table 3 . The links to the SDGs and targets were not explicit in the building brief and are thereby based on the interpretations and mapping of the researchers.

To investigate the level of implementation of the SDGs in the project at this stage, the Implementation Percentage (IP) was calculated by defining the total number of targets used for each SDG in the building brief in relation to the total number of SDG targets defined by the United Nations (UN), accordingly, evaluating the SDGs implementation impact. Three categories of data were then defined. An IP < 20%, indicates a low SDG implementation impact, an IP between 20 and 40% indicates an average implementation impact and an IP > 40% indicates a high implementation impact, as shown in Table 4 .

For example, SDG 1 for no poverty consists of 7 targets in total, defined by the UN. While in the KYU case, only one target is used. Thus, the implementation percentage for SDG1 for KYU building is 14%, indicating that it has low SDG implementation impact.
An overview of the implementation percentage for each SDG used in the KYU project is presented in Fig. 3 .

It is observed that SDG1 (No poverty), SDG 2 (Zero hunger), SDG 5 (Gender equality), SDG 10 (Reduced inequalities), SDG 16 (Peace, justice and strong institutions) and SDG 17 (Partnerships for action) have an IPÂ <Â 20%, meaning that they have a low implementation impact and are not in focus. The low SDG implementation can refer to positive social and political aspects, making it unnecessary to explicitly implement the goals in the project. For example, the lack of implementation of SDG 5 (Gender equality) and SDG 16 (Peace, justice, and strong institutions) reflects the national political strategies in democracy, providing gender equality and maintaining justice and peace, which are implicitly applicable to all building projects in Denmark. In addition, it is unclear from the building brief data whether the building contributes to SDG 10 (Reducing inequalities), therefore it is not to mentioned in the building brief analysis.

SDGs with an IP between 20 and 40% are SDG 3 (Good health and well-being), SDG 6 (Clean water and sanitation), SDG 7 (Affordable and clean energy), SDG 11 (Sustainable cities and communities), SDG 14 (Life below water) and SDG 15 (Life on land), indicating an average focus in the project. For example, an average implementation of SDG 2 (Stop hunger) may reflect the Danish society's high welfare and life quality, which does not require significant improvements in adding new features to the building. Goals 14 (Life in the sea) and 15 (Life on land) are also successfully implemented due to the project's location close to the fjord and park.

SDGs with an IP > 40% are SDG 4 (Quality education), SDG 8 (Decent jobs and economic growth), SDG 9 (Industry, innovation and infrastructure), SDG 12 (Responsible consumption and production) and SDG 13 (Climate action), indicating a high focus and implementation impact of these SDGs. As an educational institute, the project naturally contributes to and facilitate SDG 4, 8, 9, 12 and 13. For example, it is revealed in the implementation of SDG 4 (Quality education) that 5 out of 10 targets are implemented. Therefore, the contribution to SDG 4 aligns very well with the project's pedagogical goals and values.

Additionally, SDG 12 (Responsible consumption and production) is in high focus as it is one of the crucial goals to reduce the carbon footprint and waste materials by implementing circular strategies, reducing waste, reusing building materials and promoting recycling. Furthermore, SDG 13 (Climate action) is considered to have the most significant focus (60%) and the highest implementation impact on the project. Thus, it reflects the effectiveness and success of applying this SDG and aligns very well with the project vision and goals towards environmental and climate action strategies.

This paper set out to investigate how the SDGs and targets were utilised in the programming stage of a new construction project in Denmark, by exploring the decision process related to the development of a vision plan for the project through interviews with the involved actors, along with analysing the building brief. The key findings from the interviews were that the SDGs served as an overall framework for sustainability and contributed to a holistic dialogue on sustainability among the actors. Also, the SDGs were perceived as a valuable framework for dialogue with the users and stakeholders. On the contrary, the actors expressed challenges in utilising the SDGs and targets on a project specific level, due to the lack of measurability and benchmarking in relation to building projects. This aligns with the results of Gade and Opoku [8], where the professional building owners and advisors expressed similar challenges. In the Danish context, the SDG targets has been adapted to the local context with relevant indicators. However, these are still not directly transferrable to specific building projects. In this case, DGNB-DK served the purpose of assessing sustainability, whereas the SDGs and targets were only applied as an overall framework, to ensure a balanced approach to sustainability, but did not, overall, raise the bar and make the project more sustainable. Also, they used the link between DGNB criteria and SDG targets provided in the latest DGNB manual to navigate which targets were included [24]. Also, the application of the SDGs in the project contributed to the political agenda regarding sustainability, even though it was a challenge to convince the politicians that the project would not be significantly more expensive for this reason. The process of prioritising which SDGs and targets should be included in the project did not have a primary focus, as the prioritisation was led by the SDG and targets included in the overall development of the area in which the new building is located, and due to the abstract nature of the targets in relation to construction. The internal bodies within the municipality represented differing values related to different SDGs, and the SDGs served as a framework for expressing these values and to make sure a balanced set of criteria were included in the building brief, representing social, environmental, and economic aspects. The main limitation of this study is the difficulty of generalisability of the findings from a single case. The results provide in depth analysis of the process related to a single construction project, which is considered a âbest practiceâ example by the authors. The IP calculation method presented in the paper is applicable in other projects seeking to implement the SDGs, not only limited to the field of construction.

The VRK model was applied to analyse the decision context and process and was used to design the interview guide to cover the aspects of values, rules, and knowledge and the interactions between these. This was done in order to interrogate the process of developing the vision plan and building brief in the context of emerging issues of global change, in this case the SDGs. The values of the interviewees can be divided into the themes of pedagogical, technical and economical values. The KYU project explicitly seeked to contribute to 14 of the 17 SDGs, directly and indirectly, and the building itself should foster sustainability awareness for the users, and thereby invite and inspire to a more sustainable behaviour among both pupils and staff. Through the analysis of the building brief the researchers found that the project potentially contributes to all of the 17 SDGs in various degrees. The main SDG contributions were SDG 4, 9, 12 and 13, reflecting the function of the building (educational), a focus on circularity, innovation, and reducing climate change. The rules playing a role in the project is primarily the Danish building regulation, the DGNB-DK criteria and the SDGs. The knowledge aspects identified were knowledge related to the SDGs and targets, of the DGNB-DK criteria, along with specific technical and pedagogical knowledge of the actors.

This paper presents the findings related to the early stages of the KYU project â the development of a vision plan for the project along with the building brief and does therefore not necessarily reflect the impact on the final building. This study contributes to the existing body of knowledge by providing a practical example of how the SDGs can be applied in a construction project during the programming phase, along with insights on the related decision and prioritisation process. The results can benefit both actors within the construction industry, especially professional building owners and their advisors, along with researchers within the field of sustainable building design. The authors recommend future research focusing on case studies involving practical examples of SDG implementation in construction projects in order to support the operationalisation of the SDGs towards 2030, further development and testing of methods and tools to support and measure SDG implementation in construction projects, and, lastly, development and alignment of industry specific indicators.
The authors have no conflict of interests to declare.

We wish to confirm that there are no known conflicts of interest associated with this publication and there has been no significant financial support for this work that could have influenced its outcome.

We confirm that the manuscript has been read and approved by all named authors and that there are no other persons who satisfied the criteria for authorship but are not listed. We further confirm that the order of authors listed in the manuscript has been approved by all of us.

We confirm that we have given due consideration to the protection of intellectual property associated with this work and that there are no impediments to publication, including the timing of publication, with respect to intellectual property. In so doing we confirm that we have followed the regulations of our institutions concerning intellectual property.

We understand that the Corresponding Author is the sole contact for the Editorial process (including Editorial Manager and direct communications with the office). He/she is responsible for communicating with the other authors about progress, submissions of revisions and final approval of proofs. We confirm that we have provided a current, correct email address which is accessible by the Corresponding Author.

ce:conflict-of-interest.ce:para: The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.
